constructions.construction_name: PAST SIMPLE FOR EVERYDAY EVENTS AND STATES

description.rule: Can use the past simple to talk about everyday events or states.
examples: The people were very polite.
Every time I went to Hendon Park, I saw so many people there.

constructions.construction_name: MAIN CLAUSE WITH ANOTHER MAIN CLAUSE

description.rule: Can combine two main declarative clauses using co-ordinating conjunctions ('and', 'but', 'or').
examples: I like my college and I like my class.
On Sunday I visit my friends, but I often stay at home and I read books..

description.rule: Can use possessive determiners 'my', 'your', 'his', 'her' and 'our' before nouns and noun phrases and possessive pronouns
examples: I live with my family. My home is a flat.
Our house has four rooms, one bathroom and one toilet.

description.rule: Can use 'but' to join a limited range of common adjectives, after 'be'.
examples: The weather was cloudy but fine.
It was cheap but beautiful.

description.rule: Can form superlative adjective phrases using 'the most', with longer adjectives of two or more syllables.
examples: We love football competitions because here in Uruguay football is the most popular sport.
The problem was that it was the most expensive mobile in the shop.

description.rule: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('maybe', 'perhaps') to indicate degrees of certainty.
examples: Or maybe we can walk to there, because it's not far from my house.
Perhaps I left it in your living room.

constructions.construction_name: PAST CONTINUOUS FOR DESCRIBTION OF BACKGROUND EVENTS

description.rule: Can use the past continuous to show that an event was happening in the background to the main event.
examples: Yesterday we were studying maths in your house, and I left my book on your bed.
It was raining when I arrived.

constructions.construction_name: Present continuous for events in process

description.rule: Can use the present continuous with an increasing range of verbs to talk about situations and events in progress.
examples: I am watching a swimming competition.
It's June and it's getting warmer.

description.rule: Can use the '-ing' forms of verbs as nouns, in object position, to refer to activities.
examples: There we did a lot of things like swimming from the beach and going shopping.
I practised windsurfing and scuba diving.

constructions.construction_name: PRESENT CONTINUOUS FOR QUESTIONS ABOUT THE FUTURE

description.rule: Can use the present continuous with an increasing range of verbs to ask about future plans.
examples: Are you visiting my country on your next holiday?
Why are you moving to a different area?

description.rule: Can use 'than' + a finite clause forming the second part of a comparison after a comparative adjective
examples: I wish our schools could become better than they are.
He is almost 60 years old, but he's faster than you can imagine.

description.rule: Can use an increasing range of adverbs to refer to the timing of an event.
examples: Dear Kate, I went to the cinema with a new friend recently.
Dear Kate, I went to the cinema with a new friend recently.

description.rule: Can use no article before an increasing range of nouns in some fixed expressions with prepositions.
examples: The weather is very cold at night.
This programme will be shown on television next Friday.

description.rule: Can use ''s' after irregular plural nouns to indicate possession.
examples: When I go out with my friends, I actually like wearing clothes that attract people's attention.
The second reason is: it is too far from the children's school and, unfortunately, I haven't got a car.

description.rule: Can use a finite subordinate clause with conjunctions ('even though, (al)though, while if') to introduce contrast, before or after a main clause.
examples: You should come with your sister even though you would rather be alone.
Although he was famous, I didn't like him.

constructions.construction_name: Present continuous as a future form

description.rule: We often use the present continuous to talk about future events that are already planned and decided when a date and/or a place have been chosen.
examples: I’m seeing the dentist at 6.
I’m flying to New York tomorrow morning.

constructions.construction_name: Reported speech using a reporting clause

description.rule: Can report speech and thought directly using the reporting verb in the mid position of the reported clause.
examples: 'No problem', I thought, 'there is only one person'.
'Forgive me, sweetheart', he said, 'I will never leave you alone again.'

description.rule: Can use 'will' (particularly 'Will you please') to make requests and commands in a wide range of contexts.
examples: Will you please send me his name, address and telephone number.
Will you pay attention!

description.rule: Can use the future perfect continuous to look back to the past from a point in the future and to emphasise the duration of an activity or event.
examples: Now I am staying in Hastings in England and this month, I will have been studying English for seven months.
I think I could have a holiday just in July because I will have been working for my company for one year by the end of the June.

description.rule: Can use the past perfect continuous to talk about events which started before a time in the past and which finished, but where the effects or results were still important at a point in the past.
examples: Unfortunately it had been snowing for a long time and so I was unable to go out for a walk.
We had been working very hard all the morning so by that time, I was very tired.

description.rule: Can use 'yes/no', 'wh-', tag and negative question forms with an increasing range of verbs.
examples: Are you still looking for a job or did you succeed in finding one?
It was great to have met you, and we certainly had a terrific time together, didn't we?

description.rule: Can use a wide range of compound adjectives ('open-minded', 'above-mentioned', 'well-to-do', 'jaw-dropping')
examples: I would describe myself as an easy-going and open-minded person.
But as she does not live in a well-to-do family, Ola was never able to afford additional private lessons, for example. .

description.rule: Can use 'can' in passive reporting clauses in a more formal impersonal style (e.g. for reports and academic contexts), such as 'It can be said that'
examples: It can be argued, looking at the figures, that the company should consider withdrawing from the heater market.
Taking everything into account, it can be concluded that the current training course is very useful for our company.

description.rule: Can use a passive non-finite '-ing' form as a subordinate clause or a noun clause to give explanatory background information.
examples: Being born and raised in Mexico, I believe her to be this country's best representative to the world.
Being invited by your boss for an unexpected lunch makes you feel noticed.
